critique: The document re-establishes the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) and continues its existence until July 1, 1935. The NLRB was originally created under Executive Order No. 6763 of June 29, 1934. The document states that the NLRB shall exercise the powers and functions and be charged with the duties prescribed in Executive Order No. 6763 of June 29, 1934, in so far as such powers, functions, and duties are authorized under the National Industrial Recovery Act as amended and continued by the said Senate Joint Resolution No. 113. The National Industrial Recovery Act was part of FDR's New Deal legislation. The re-establishment of the NLRB suggests a liberal ideological tilt, as it supports labor rights and collective bargaining. The document does not directly address immigration, executive power, federalism, national security vs. civil liberties, or social inclusion. However, the re-establishment of the NLRB implies government intervention in the economy to regulate labor relations. Therefore, the economic regulation score is positive. The document does not seem to promote conformity or diversity, so the social inclusion score is neutral.
